title: 112_hr1603
content: The United States has had persistent trade deficits since 1978, with significant deficits with countries like China, the European Union, Japan, and Mexico. Despite having an open economy, the US faces trade barriers with its partners. Establishment of the Emergency Trade Deficit Commission with 11 members appointed by the President, Senate leaders, and committee members to represent various interests. The Emergency Trade Deficit Commission consists of 11 members appointed by the President, Senate leaders, and House representatives. Members must have expertise in economics, with restrictions on executive branch affiliations for presidential appointees. The Emergency Trade Deficit Commission consists of 11 members appointed based on expertise in economics, international trade, manufacturing, labor, environment, or business. Members should not be US officers or employees, and efforts are made to ensure a diverse representation of economic and trade perspectives. Recommendations are sought to address structural trade imbalances. Members are appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Emergency Trade Deficit Commission consists of 11 members appointed based on expertise in economics, international trade, manufacturing, labor, environment, or business. Members should not be US officers or employees, and efforts are made to ensure a diverse representation of economic and trade perspectives. Recommendations are sought to address structural trade imbalances. Members are appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission's vacancies do not affect its powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, and meetings are called by the Chairperson. The members elect a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson, and a majority constitutes a quorum for decision-making. Each member has one equal vote. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with examining the causes of the US trade deficit, including macroeconomic factors like currency practices and foreign government purchases of US assets. They will also assess the impact of tariff and nontariff barriers on trade deficits with specific countries. The Commission will analyze the impact of tariff and nontariff barriers, investment requirements, technology transfer, labor standards adherence, environmental protection levels, and policies supporting manufacturers in specific countries. The Commission will examine the impact of free trade agreements, investment flows, and foreign direct investment on the United States trade deficit, including the effects of outbound investment and production relocation overseas. The Commission will analyze the impact of foreign direct investment and bilateral investment treaties on the US trade deficit, as well as the role of energy imports. It will also assess how US foreign policy influences economic and trade policies, and examine the consequences of the trade deficit on the domestic economy, manufacturing capacity, and job quality. The Commission will assess the impact of trade deficits on manufacturing capacity, job quality, wages, and economic growth. Recommendations will include strategies to improve trade balances, use trade policy tools effectively, and enhance competitiveness of US manufacturers. The Commission will assess the impact of trade deficits on manufacturing capacity, job quality, wages, and economic growth. Recommendations will include strategies to improve trade balances, use trade policy tools effectively, and enhance competitiveness of US manufacturers. Additionally, the Commission will address ways to improve coordination and accountability of Federal departments and agencies relating to trade, and examine ways to enhance the collection and reporting of trade data to properly assess the causes and consequences of the United States trade deficit. The Commission will submit a report to the President and relevant committees containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for administrative and legislative actions. Members can also include separate views in the report. The Commission is granted powers to fulfill its duties. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. Additionally, the Commission has personnel matters to address. The Commission members receive compensation based on their status as federal employees or not, with travel expenses covered. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint and terminate an executive director and additional personnel necessary for the Commission's duties. The compensation for these positions can be set by the Chairperson without following certain federal pay regulations. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and the Chairperson can procure temporary and intermittent services as needed. The Chairperson of the Commission can procure temporary services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 7. Authorization of $2,000,000 for the Commission to carry out the Act. GAO to audit Commission's financial books within 6 months of termination. SEC. 8. Commission terminates 30 days after report submission. SEC. 9. Moratorium on free trade agreements until Commission's report is delivered.
